symptomTracker.title: Daily Symptom Tracker
symptomTracker.promptTemplate: I'm experiencing the following symptoms during menstruation: {symptoms}. Please provide: 1. Self-care tips 2. Foods to eat 3. Foods to avoid 4. General care or avoidance tips. Format the response in JSON with these keys: selfCareTips, foodsToEat, foodsToAvoid, generalTips. Each should be an array of strings.

selfCare.title: Nurture Your Cycle: A Garden of Self-Care

tips.description: Practice deep, slow breathing for 5 minutes. Inhale for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 6. This can help reduce stress and alleviate menstrual cramps.
Apply a warm compress to your lower abdomen for 15-20 minutes. This can help relax muscles and reduce menstrual pain. Remember to wrap the compress in a towel to protect your skin.

Use essential oils like lavender, clary sage, or peppermint. Add a few drops to a diffuser or mix with a carrier oil for a soothing massage. These scents can help balance hormones and reduce discomfort.
Spend 10 minutes writing about your feelings, experiences, and any physical symptoms. This can help you track patterns and provide emotional release.

Try gentle yoga poses like Child's Pose, Cat-Cow, or Reclined Bound Angle. Hold each pose for 30 seconds to 1 minute, focusing on deep breathing. This can help relieve tension and improve circulation.
Practice 10-15 minutes of meditation daily. This can help reduce stress, improve emotional balance, and alleviate menstrual symptoms.
Drink calming herbal teas like chamomile, ginger, or peppermint. These can help soothe cramps and promote relaxation.

tips.name: Iron-rich foods
tips.description: Incorporate foods like spinach, lentils, and lean red meat. Aim for 18mg of iron per day. Pair with vitamin C-rich foods to enhance absorption. This helps replenish iron lost during menstruation.

tips.name: Omega-3 fatty acids
tips.description: Include salmon, chia seeds, and walnuts in your diet. Aim for 1.1g per day. Omega-3s can help reduce inflammation and alleviate menstrual pain.

tips.name: Magnesium-rich foods
tips.description: Eat dark chocolate (70% cocoa or higher), avocados, and almonds. Aim for 310-320mg daily. Magnesium can help reduce cramps, fatigue, and mood swings.

tips.name: Hydrating foods
tips.description: Consume water-rich foods like cucumber, watermelon, and celery. Aim to drink 8-10 glasses of water daily. Proper hydration can help reduce bloating and alleviate menstrual symptoms.

tips.name: Probiotic-rich foods
tips.description: Include yogurt, kefir, and sauerkraut in your diet. Aim for 1-2 servings daily. Probiotics support gut health, which can help reduce menstrual discomfort and improve overall well-being.

tips.name: Calcium-rich foods
tips.description: Include dairy products, leafy greens, and fortified plant milks. Aim for 1000mg daily. Calcium can help reduce mood swings and cramps.

tips.name: Complex carbohydrates
tips.description: Consume whole grains, quinoa, and sweet potatoes. These provide steady energy and can help stabilize mood swings.

tips.name: Gentle Yoga
tips.description: Practice gentle yoga for 20-30 minutes. Focus on poses like Child's Pose, Cat-Cow, and Reclined Twist. These can help ease cramps, improve circulation, and promote relaxation.

tips.name: Low-impact cardio
tips.description: Engage in 30 minutes of light walking or swimming. This can boost endorphins, improve mood, and reduce menstrual discomfort. Remember to listen to your body and adjust intensity as needed.

tips.name: Stretching
tips.description: Perform gentle stretches for 10-15 minutes, focusing on the lower back, hips, and thighs. Hold each stretch for 30 seconds. This can help alleviate tension and improve flexibility.

tips.name: Adequate sleep
tips.description: Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep. Maintain a consistent sleep schedule and create a relaxing bedtime routine. Good sleep supports hormonal balance and overall well-being during menstruation.

tips.name: Mindful rest
tips.description: Take 3-5 minute breaks throughout the day for deep breathing or short meditation. This can help manage stress levels, reduce tension, and improve overall comfort during your cycle.

tips.name: Pilates
tips.description: Try a 20-30 minute Pilates session. This low-impact exercise can strengthen your core, improve posture, and alleviate back pain associated with menstruation.

tips.name: Nature walk
tips.description: Take a 30-minute walk in nature. This can boost your mood, reduce stress, and provide gentle exercise to ease menstrual discomfort.

recipeData.youtubeQuery: quick healthy breakfast recipes during menopause

mythList.title: You cannot get pregnant during your period
mythList.content: While it is less likely, pregnancy can still occur during menstruation. Sperm can survive in the body for up to 5 days, and ovulation timing can vary.

mythList.title: Menstruation is always painful
mythList.content: While many women experience some discomfort, severe pain is not normal and could indicate an underlying condition like endometriosis.

mythList.title: You shouldnt exercise during your period
mythList.content: Exercise can actually help alleviate cramps and boost mood. Listen to your body and adjust intensity as needed.

mythList.title: PMS is all in your head
mythList.content: PMS is a real condition caused by hormonal changes. It can affect both physical and emotional well-being.

questions.question: What is a normal menstrual cycle length?
questions.answer: A typical menstrual cycle lasts between 21 to 35 days, with the average being 28 days. However, cycle lengths can vary from person to person and even from month to month.

questions.question: How much blood loss is normal during a period?
questions.answer: The average blood loss during a period is about 30 to 80 ml. This is equivalent to 2 to 5 tablespoons. Anything significantly more than this could be considered heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.question: When should I see a doctor about my period?
questions.answer: You should consult a doctor if you experience very heavy bleeding, severe pain, irregular cycles, or if your period lasts longer than 7 days. Also, seek medical advice if you miss three or more periods in a row.

questions.question: Can stress affect my menstrual cycle?
questions.answer: Yes, stress can affect your menstrual cycle. It can lead to delayed periods, heavier or lighter flows, or even skipped periods. Managing stress through relaxation techniques can help regulate your cycle.

symptomTracker.title: Weekly Pregnancy Symptom Tracker
symptomTracker.promptTemplate: I'm experiencing the following symptoms during pregnancy: {symptoms}. Please provide: 1. Self-care tips 2. Foods to eat 3. Foods to avoid 4. General care or avoidance tips. Format the response in JSON with these keys: selfCareTips, foodsToEat, foodsToAvoid, generalTips. Each should be an array of strings.

selfCare.title: Nurturing Your Pregnancy: A Garden of Self-Care

tips.description: Practice 20-30 minutes of prenatal yoga daily. Focus on gentle stretches and breathing exercises. This can help reduce stress, improve sleep, and prepare your body for labor.
Spend 10-15 minutes daily in quiet meditation, focusing on your connection with your baby. This can reduce anxiety and promote bonding with your unborn child.
Treat yourself to a prenatal massage every 2-4 weeks. This can help alleviate back pain, reduce swelling, and improve overall comfort during pregnancy.

Create a daily hydration routine. Aim for 8-10 glasses of water, and keep a reusable water bottle with you. Proper hydration supports amniotic fluid levels and can help prevent premature contractions.

Spend 30 minutes each day preparing your home for baby. This can include organizing the nursery, baby-proofing, or creating a postpartum care station. Purposeful nesting can reduce anxiety and increase feelings of preparedness.

Take 10 minutes each evening to write in a pregnancy journal. Record your feelings, physical changes, and milestones. This practice can help process emotions and create a beautiful keepsake of your journey.
Aim for a 20-30 minute gentle walk daily, preferably in nature. This low-impact exercise can improve circulation, boost mood, and help maintain a healthy pregnancy weight.

tips.name: Folic Acid-rich foods
tips.description: Incorporate leafy greens, fortified cereals, and legumes. Aim for 600-800 mcg daily. Folic acid is crucial for preventing neural tube defects in early pregnancy.

tips.name: Calcium sources
tips.description: Include dairy products, fortified plant milks, and leafy greens. Aim for 1000mg daily. Calcium supports the development of your baby's bones and teeth.

tips.name: Iron-rich foods
tips.description: Consume lean meats, beans, and fortified cereals. Aim for 27mg daily. Iron supports increased blood volume and prevents anemia during pregnancy.

tips.name: Omega-3 fatty acids
tips.description: Include fatty fish (in moderation), chia seeds, and walnuts. Aim for 200-300mg of DHA daily. Omega-3s support fetal brain and eye development.

tips.name: Protein sources
tips.description: Eat lean meats, eggs, legumes, and dairy. Aim for 75-100g daily. Protein is essential for your baby's growth and your body's changing needs.

tips.name: Vitamin D
tips.description: Get sunlight exposure and consume fortified foods. Aim for 600 IU daily. Vitamin D supports calcium absorption and bone health for both you and your baby.

tips.name: Probiotics
tips.description: Include yogurt, kefir, and fermented foods. Probiotics support your digestive health and may reduce the risk of complications like gestational diabetes.

exerciseRest.title: Balancing Activity and Rest During Pregnancy

tips.name: Prenatal Swimming
tips.description: Try swimming for 30 minutes, 2-3 times a week. This low-impact exercise is excellent for cardiovascular health and can help alleviate pregnancy discomforts.

tips.name: Pelvic Floor Exercises
tips.description: Practice Kegel exercises for 5 minutes, 3 times daily. This can help prevent urinary incontinence and prepare your body for labor.

tips.name: Pregnancy Pilates
tips.description: Attend a prenatal Pilates class once a week. This can help maintain core strength and improve posture as your body changes.

tips.name: Adequate Sleep
tips.description: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep nightly. Create a comfortable sleep environment and consider using a pregnancy pillow for support.

tips.name: Gentle Stretching
tips.description: Spend 10-15 minutes daily on gentle stretching. Focus on your back, hips, and legs to alleviate pregnancy-related aches and pains.

tips.name: Mindful Rest Periods
tips.description: Take 3-4 short rest periods throughout the day. Use this time to practice deep breathing and connect with your baby.

tips.name: Prenatal Strength Training
tips.description: Engage in light strength training 2-3 times a week. Use bodyweight exercises or light weights to maintain muscle tone and support your changing body.

pregnancy.title: Breakfast Ideas

mythList.title: Eating for two means doubling your food intake
mythList.content: You only need about 300-500 extra calories per day during pregnancy. Focus on nutrient-dense foods rather than increasing quantity drastically.

mythList.title: You cant exercise during pregnancy
mythList.content: Most women can and should exercise during pregnancy. Always consult your healthcare provider, but moderate exercise is generally safe and beneficial.

mythList.title: Cocoa butter prevents stretch marks
mythList.content: While moisturizing can help with skin elasticity, stretch marks are largely determined by genetics and how quickly you gain weight.

mythList.title: You cant dye your hair during pregnancy
mythList.content: Modern hair dyes are generally considered safe during pregnancy. If concerned, consult your doctor or consider natural alternatives.

questions.question: When should I start taking prenatal vitamins?
questions.answer: Ideally, you should start taking prenatal vitamins before conception. If you're already pregnant, start as soon as possible. Folic acid is particularly important in the first trimester.

questions.question: Is it safe to travel during pregnancy?
questions.answer: In most cases, it's safe to travel during pregnancy, especially in the second trimester. However, consult your healthcare provider before making travel plans, especially for long distances or to areas with limited medical facilities.

questions.question: How much weight should I gain during pregnancy?
questions.answer: Weight gain recommendations vary based on your pre-pregnancy BMI. Generally, a healthy weight gain is 25-35 pounds for women with a normal BMI. Consult your healthcare provider for personalized advice.

questions.question: When will I feel the baby move?
questions.answer: Most first-time mothers feel fetal movement, often called 'quickening', between 18-25 weeks of pregnancy. Experienced mothers might feel movement earlier, around 16-18 weeks.

tips.name: Relaxation techniques
tips.description: Practice deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery for 10-15 minutes daily to manage stress and improve sleep.

mythList.title: Perimenopause always starts in your 40s
mythList.content: Perimenopause can begin in your 30s or 40s. The timing varies for each woman and can last anywhere from 2 to 10 years.

mythList.title: You can't get pregnant during perimenopause
mythList.content: While fertility declines, pregnancy is still possible until you've gone 12 months without a period. Contraception is still necessary if you don't want to become pregnant.

mythList.title: Hormone therapy is dangerous for everyone
mythList.content: For many women, the benefits of hormone therapy outweigh the risks. It's important to discuss your individual situation with your healthcare provider.

mythList.title: Weight gain during perimenopause is inevitable
mythList.content: While metabolism slows down, weight gain isn't inevitable. Regular exercise and a balanced diet can help maintain a healthy weight.

questions.question: How long does perimenopause last?
questions.answer: Perimenopause can last anywhere from 2 to 10 years. On average, most women experience perimenopausal symptoms for about 4 years before reaching menopause.

questions.question: What's the difference between perimenopause and menopause?
questions.answer: Perimenopause is the transition period leading up to menopause. Menopause is officially diagnosed when you've gone 12 consecutive months without a menstrual period.

questions.question: Can I still get pregnant during perimenopause?
questions.answer: Yes, it's still possible to get pregnant during perimenopause. If you don't want to become pregnant, you should continue using contraception until you've gone 12 months without a period.

questions.question: Are there natural ways to manage perimenopausal symptoms?
questions.answer: Yes, many women find relief through lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, stress reduction techniques, dietary adjustments, and herbal remedies. However, it's important to discuss any new treatments with your healthcare provider.

Use a gentle moisturizer daily and protect your skin from sun damage to combat dryness and maintain skin health.
Maintain strong social connections. Spend time with friends or join a support group to share experiences and reduce feelings of isolation.

mythList.title: Menopause always starts at 50
mythList.content: The average age for menopause is 51, but it can occur anywhere between 45 and 55. Some women may experience it earlier or later.

mythList.title: Menopause symptoms last only a few years
mythList.content: While most intense symptoms may last 2-3 years, some women experience symptoms for much longer, even into post-menopause.

mythList.title: Weight gain during menopause is inevitable
mythList.content: While metabolism slows down, weight gain isn't inevitable. Regular exercise and a balanced diet can help maintain a healthy weight.

mythList.title: You don't need to worry about birth control after menopause
mythList.content: You should continue using birth control until you've gone 12 consecutive months without a period, as pregnancy is still possible during the menopausal transition.

questions.question: How do I know if I've reached menopause?
questions.answer: Menopause is officially diagnosed when you've gone 12 consecutive months without a menstrual period. However, the transition to menopause (perimenopause) can last several years and is often accompanied by symptoms like irregular periods, hot flashes, and mood changes.

questions.question: Is hormone therapy safe for managing menopausal symptoms?
questions.answer: Hormone therapy can be effective for managing menopausal symptoms like hot flashes and vaginal dryness. However, it's not suitable for everyone. The risks and benefits should be discussed with your healthcare provider to determine if it's right for you.

questions.question: Can I still get pregnant after menopause?
questions.answer: Once you've reached menopause (12 months without a period), you can no longer get pregnant naturally. However, during the menopausal transition, pregnancy is still possible, so contraception should be used until menopause is confirmed.

questions.question: Are there natural remedies for managing menopausal symptoms?
questions.answer: Some women find relief from menopausal symptoms through lifestyle changes, dietary adjustments, and natural remedies like black cohosh or evening primrose oil. However, the effectiveness of these varies, and it's important to discuss any treatments with your healthcare provider.
